text:
continuous function from subspace [imath]\mathbb{Q}[/imath] to [imath]\mathbb{R}[/imath]

f:[imath]\mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}[/imath] such that f(x)=a, for all x[imath]\in\mathbb{R}[/imath] is continuous function.
[imath]\mathbb{Q}[/imath]  is a subspace of [imath]\mathbb{R}[/imath] and hence  f:[imath]\mathbb{Q} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}[/imath] such that f(x)=a, for all x[imath]\in\mathbb{Q}[/imath] is also continuous function with respect to subspace topology.
Using sequential continuity i can see that the function f:[imath]\mathbb{Q} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}[/imath] such that f(x)=a, for all x[imath]\in\mathbb{Q}[/imath] is continuous.
But if  i will think in this way , {a} is closed in  [imath]\mathbb{R}[/imath] and under continuous function  inverse image of closed set is closed   that is [imath]f^{-1}[/imath](a)=[imath]\mathbb{Q}[/imath] is closed. which is not possible because 
 [imath]\mathbb{Q}[/imath] is not closed subspace of  [imath]\mathbb{R}[/imath].   hence f:[imath]\mathbb{Q} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}[/imath] such that f(x)=a, for all x[imath]\in\mathbb{Q}[/imath] is not continuous.
where i am going wrong.

Possible duplicate of continuous function from [imath]\mathbb{Q}[/imath] to [imath]\mathbb{R}[/imath]

However, [imath]\Bbb Q[/imath] is closed in [imath]\Bbb Q[/imath].
When analysing the continuity of a function [imath]g:A\to B[/imath], then you need to analyse, for any open / closed [imath]U\subseteq B[/imath], whether [imath]f^{-1}(U)[/imath] is open / closed in [imath]A[/imath]. It doesn't matter whether [imath]A[/imath] is thought of as a subspace of some larger space; in this context that larger space does not exist for our intents and purposes.
So in our case, when we have a function [imath]f:\Bbb Q\to \Bbb R[/imath], you must forget that [imath]\Bbb Q[/imath] is a part of [imath]\Bbb R[/imath], and just look at [imath]\Bbb Q[/imath] as a topological space in its own right.
